---
title: "Spain contribution to European GDP growth"
date: "2025-03-15"
categories: [GDP, Eurostat]
execute:
  warning: false
  message: false
---


A journalist recently asked us if an statement from a politician was true. The statement was that Spain represented half of the European growth. In this (first) post we would learn how to do it using Eurostat data.

## Annual data

First, I will show the more direct way to do it for annual data. If we want to calculate it for 2024 we need to get the data for Spain and the EU (or Euro area) for 2023 in current prices and for 2024 in previous year prices (prices of 2023). By difference we can calculate the volume change in both areas.

First we load the libraries.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(eurostat)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
```
:::


And we prepare a query for the data we need. First, the year 2023 in current prices:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dat_23 <- get_eurostat("nama_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("CP_MEUR"),
                                   time_period = 2023),
                    time_format = "num") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_23)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|geo       | time|   values|
|:---------|----:|--------:|
|EU27_2020 | 2023| 17197822|
|EA20      | 2023| 14598181|
|ES        | 2023|  1498324|


:::
:::


And after the 2024 in previous year prices


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dat_24 <- get_eurostat("nama_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("PYP_MEUR"),
                                   time_period = 2024),
                    time_format = "num") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_24)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|geo       | time|   values|
|:---------|----:|--------:|
|EU27_2020 | 2024| 17372727|
|EA20      | 2024| 14722950|
|ES        | 2024|  1546966|


:::
:::


We bind them together and calculate the change between 2024 and 2023:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dat <- bind_rows(dat_23, dat_24) |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = time,
              values_from = values) |> 
  mutate(change = `2024` - `2023`,
         change_p = round(change / `2023` * 100, 2))  

knitr::kable(dat)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|geo       |     2023|     2024|   change| change_p|
|:---------|--------:|--------:|--------:|--------:|
|EU27_2020 | 17197822| 17372727| 174905.4|     1.02|
|EA20      | 14598181| 14722950| 124768.8|     0.85|
|ES        |  1498324|  1546966|  48642.0|     3.25|


:::
:::


Spain grew by 3.25 in 2024 and the EU  by 1.02. But as we are looking for the contribution, we need to divide the change in Spain with the change in the EU.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cont_es_24_eu <- round(dat |> filter(geo == "ES") |> select(change) |> pull() / 
                       dat |> filter(geo == "EU27_2020") |> select(change) |> pull()
                       * 100, 2)

cont_es_24_ea <- round(dat |> filter(geo == "ES") |> select(change) |> pull() / 
                       dat |> filter(geo == "EA20") |> select(change) |> pull()
                       * 100, 2)
```
:::



For the EU the contribution was 27.81 and for the Euro area 38.99.

## Quarterly data

In the case of quarterly data, for example comparing the fourth quarter of 2024 with the fourth quarter of 2023, we cannot compared current prices in 2023Q4, which are at the prices of 2023Q4, with the previous year prices of 2024. The easiest way is to use the 2023Q4 in current prices as a kind of weights for the start of the period and calculate the change between 2024Q4 and 2023Q4 in chain linked series.

First the current prices.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dat_23_q4 <- get_eurostat("namq_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("CP_MEUR"),
                                   s_adj = "SCA",
                                   time_period = "2024-Q4"),
                    time_format = "raw") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_23_q4)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|geo       |time    |  values|
|:---------|:-------|-------:|
|EU27_2020 |2024-Q4 | 4554634|
|EA20      |2024-Q4 | 3842814|
|ES        |2024-Q4 |  407457|


:::
:::


And then the chain linked data.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dat_24_q4 <- get_eurostat("namq_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("CLV20_MEUR"),
                                   s_adj = "SCA",
                                   time_period = c("2023-Q4","2024-Q4")),
                    time_format = "raw") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_24_q4)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|geo       |time    |  values|
|:---------|:-------|-------:|
|EU27_2020 |2023-Q4 | 3758731|
|EU27_2020 |2024-Q4 | 3810585|
|EA20      |2023-Q4 | 3213335|
|EA20      |2024-Q4 | 3250471|
|ES        |2023-Q4 |  331427|
|ES        |2024-Q4 |  342982|


:::
:::


We compute the change between 2024Q4 and 2023Q4.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
q_change <- dat_24_q4 |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = time,
              values_from = values) |> 
  mutate(change_p = round(`2024-Q4` / `2023-Q4` * 100-100, 3))
```
:::


Spain grew by 3.486 between 2024Q4 and 2023Q4 and the EU  by 1.38.
